facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 1947 of 1968 from judgment and decree dated January 21, 1964 of Allahabad High Court in Misc. Income-tax Reference No. 383 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1947 of 1968. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 21, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Misc. Income-tax Reference No. 383 of 1958.

facts.text: The assessee is a firm constituted under an instrument of partnership dated April 30, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a firm companystituted under an Instrument, of partnership dated April 30, 1947.

facts.text: Partners' shares in profit and loss: L. Khanjan Lal 4/16, L. Lalloo Ram 2/16, L. Dwarka Prasad 2/16, L. Ram Lal 2/16, L. Sewak Ram 4/16, Smt. Jagrani Devi 2/16.

anchor.surface_text: The shares of the partners in, the profit and loss of the firm as mentioned in that deed are as follows L. Khanjan Lal--/4/- L. Lalloo Ram- -/2/ L. Dwarka Prasad- -/2/- L. Ram Lal- -/2/- L. Sewak Ram- -/4/- Smt. Jagrani Devi- -/2/-

facts.text: Lallu Ram, Dwarka Prasad and Ram Lal are children of Khanjan Lal; Sewak Ram is son of Jagrani Devi.

anchor.surface_text: Lallu Ram, Dwarka Prasad and Ram Lal are the children of- Khanjan Lad. Sewak Ram is the son of Jagrani Devi.

facts.text: First group has 10/16 share, second group has 6/16 share.

anchor.surface_text: The first group has - 10/- share in the profit and loss of the firm and the second group has -/6/- share.

facts.text: Assessee firm was registered for assessment year 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: The assesesee firm was registered for the assessment year 1947-48.

facts.text: On July 12, 1949, partners applied to ITO for renewal of registration for 1948-49, signed by all, with certificate that profits divided as shown.

anchor.surface_text: On July 12, 1949, the partners of the firm applied to the Income-tax Officer for renewal of the registration for the assessment year 1948-49. That application was signed by all the partners. To that application they appended a certificate to the. effect that profits of the previous year were divided or credited as shown below.

facts.text: Partnership dissolved on November 5, 1949 under deed dated November 9, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On November 5, 1949, the partner-ship was dissolved under a deed of distribution dated November 9, 1949

facts.text: Dissolution deed clause: if amount not entered in books found, accountable person is who received/paid it, no objection.

anchor.surface_text: One of the clauses in that deed provides But if an amount which was number entered in the books at the time of settlement is found then only that person will be accountable for it through whom the money was received or paid. None of the parties will have any objection to it.

facts.text: On October 5, 1950, first four partners disclosed to ITO that firm earned Rs.15,000 profits outside books, divided between partners.

anchor.surface_text: On October 5, 1950, the first four partners made a disclosure statement to the Income-tax Officer to the effect that the firm had earned Rs. 15,000/- by way of profits outside the books. In that disclosure statement, they further stated that those profits had been divided between the partners.

facts.text: On December 9, 1950, Sewak Ram stated on oath before ITO that he and mother got only shares of recorded profits; unrecorded profits Rs.1,13,571; withdrew registration application as profits not divided per shares.

anchor.surface_text: On December 9, 1950, Sewak Ram, one of the partners stated on oath before the Income-tax Officer that he and his mother Jagrani Devi were number given full share of the profits of the business earned by the firm in Sam v. year 2005. He further stated that the entire profits earned in that business carried on in the previous year were number recorded in the books and the first four partners had given to him and his mother only their shares of those profits which were recorded in the books. Therein he sought to withdraw the application for registration because all the profits earned had number been divided according to the shares. According to Sewak Ram, the profits ,earned and number entered in the accounts amounted to Rs. 1,13,571/-

facts.text: Firm evaded tax by not bringing portion of profits into books.

anchor.surface_text: From the aforementioned statements, it s clear that the firm was trying to evade tax on a portion of the profits .earned by it by number bringing the same into their books.

facts.text: On March 31, 1951, Sewak Ram sued first four partners for rendition of accounts, estimated his share of unentered profits at Rs.50,000.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1951, Sewak Ram sued the first four partners for rendition of accounts. In that suit he estimated his share of profits in the amount that had number been entered in the account books at Rs. 50,0001.

facts.text: Suit compromised; Sewak Ram withdrew suit stating not entitled to more amount.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately the suit was companypromised and Sewak Ram withdrew his suit. In his application to withdraw the suit, he stated that he wanted to withdraw the suit in view of the circumstances of the above case, an expression of utmost ambiguity. Therein he stated that he is number entitled to get any more amount from the defendants.

facts.text: On March 15, 1952, Sewak Ram and Jagrani Devi applied to ITO withdrawing signatures on renewal application as profits not distributed per deed, no certificates granted.

anchor.surface_text: On March 15, 1952, Sewak Ram and his mother Jagrani Devi gave an application to the Income-tax Officer stating that they are withdrawing their signatures on the application for renewal of registration as the profits of the previous year were number distributed according to the deed of partnership and the certificate of registration required under rule 4 1  of the Income-tax Rules, 1922  to be hereinafter referred to as the Rules  framed under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  in brief the Act  had never been granted as required by law on the back of the partnership deed. Therein they further stated that as the certificate under rule 6 had number been granted by the assessee in accordance with law, the firm was number entitled for registration under rule 6 of the Rules.

facts.text: ITO refused renewal of registration, taxed firm as association of persons, as black profits not distributed per deed and application withdrawn.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the material before him, the Income-tax Officer came to the companyclusion that the firm had earned companysiderable black market profits, and the same had number been distributed amongst the partners according to the partnership deed and therefore the firm was number entitled for renewal of the registration. He further opined that the application for registration had stood withdrawn. On the basis of those companyclusions, he refused to renew the registration of the firm and taxed the firm in the status of association of persons.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO's decision.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, upheld the decision of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal: members found substantial unbooked profits not distributed per partnership deed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee took the matter in appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. The two members who heard the appeal ,concurred with the Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner that a substantial portion of the profits earned by the firm had number been entered in the books. They also held that those profits were number distributed amongst the partners according to the Instrument of partnership.

facts.text: Tribunal Judicial member: no renewal; Accountant member: yes as book profits distributed; President agreed with Judicial member.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of those findings the Judicial member held that the firm was number entitled to the renewal of registration asked for but the Accountant member opined that inasmuch as the profits that had been entered in the books had been distributed, there was companypliance with the provisions of the Act as well as the, Rules. In view of this difference of opinion between the two members, the matter was referred to the President of the Tribunal under s. 5A 7  of the Act. The President agreed with the Judicial Member that firm was number entitled to have the renewal of the registration asked for.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court under s.66(1): firm entitled to renewal if book profits distributed but black profits not?

anchor.surface_text: There- after at the instance of the assessee, the Tribual submitted the following question to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Act. Whether the assessee firm which had distributed its book profits amongst the partners according to the Instrument of Partnership but which had number distributed the profits earned by it in the black market amongst the six partners in accordance with the Instrument of Partnership was entitled for renewal of registration for the assessment year 1948-49 ?

facts.text: High Court answered question in favour of Department.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered that question in favour of the Department.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by certificate from assessee firm.

anchor.surface_text: Hence this appeal by the assessee firm.

facts.text: Tribunal findings: 1. book profits distributed per deed; 2. black profits not distributed per deed. SC bound by these findings.

anchor.surface_text: Now turning to the question referred to the High Court, that question is based on two findings of fact which are numbermore open to question. Those findings are  1  that the firm had distributed its book profits amongst the partners according to the Instrument of partnership,  2  but it had number distributed the profits earned by it in the black market amongst the six partners in accordance with the Instrument of partnership.

facts.text: Application for renewal did not comply with para 3 of rule 6 as certificate false; unbooked profits not divided.

anchor.surface_text: As seen earlier, the finding of the Tribunal is that though the profits of the firm entered in its account books had been distributed, the profits earned but number entered into the account books have number been divided or credit in the account books. From that it follows that the certificate given in the application for renewal of registration is number a true certificate and further that a substantial portion of the profits earned had number been divided.

anchor.surface_text: Section 26  A  of the Act reads Application may be made to the Income-tax Officer on behalf of any firm, companystituted under an ins- trument of partnership specifying the individual shares of the partners, for registration for the purposes of this Act and of any other enactment for the time being in force relating to income-,tax or super-tax. The application shall be made by such person or persons and at such times and shall companytain such particulars and shall be in such form, and be verified in such manner, as may be prescribed and it shall be dealt with by the Income-tax Officer in such manner as may be prescribed.

concepts.interpretation: Conditions of registration: application in prescribed form, firm under instrument specifying shares, valid existing partnership; ITO bound to register if fulfilled; same for renewal.

It further provides If the Income-tax Officer is number satisfied he shall pass an order in writing refusing to renew the registration of the firm.

anchor.surface_text: On March 15, 1952, Sewak Ram and his mother Jagrani Devi gave an application to the Income-tax Officer stating that they are withdrawing their signatures on the application for renewal of registration as the profits of the previous year were not distributed according to the deed of partnership and the certificate of registration required under rule 4(1) of the Income-tax Rules, 1922... the firm was not entitled for registration under rule 6 of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Before examining the scope of the question submitted to the High Court under s. 66(1) of the Act, we may mention that the question whether the application for renewal of registration stood withdrawn or not is not before us.

holdings.text: The assessee firm which had distributed its book profits amongst the partners according to the Instrument of Partnership but which had not distributed the profits earned by it in the black market amongst the six partners in accordance with the Instrument of Partnership was not entitled for renewal of registration for the assessment year 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the assessee firm which had distributed its book profits amongst the partners according to the Instrument of Partnership but which had number distributed the profits earned by it in the black market amongst the six partners in accordance with the Instrument of Partnership was entitled for renewal of registration for the assessment year 1948-49 ? The High Court answered that question in favour of the Department.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal findings binding: book profits distributed but black profits not; certificate in renewal application false as unbooked profits not divided/credited, violating para 3 rule 6; purpose prevents tax evasion on undivided profits.

holdings.text: The application for renewal of registration did not comply with the requirements of paragraph 3 of rule 6 as the certificate was not true since unbooked profits were not divided or credited.

anchor.surface_text: As seen earlier, the finding of the Tribunal is that though the profits of the firm entered in its account books had been distributed, the profits earned but number entered into the account books have number been divided or credit in the account books. From that it follows that the certificate given in the application for renewal of registration is number a true certificate and further that a substantial portion of the profits earned had number been divided.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal finding that unbooked profits not divided means certificate falsely states profits divided/credited as shown; non-compliance with rule 6 para 3.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer was justified in refusing to renew the registration of the firm.

anchor.surface_text: Hence we must hold that the application for renewal of registration made by the assessee did number companyply with companyditions prescribed in paragraph 3 of rule 6. Hence the Income-tax Officer was justified to refuse to renew the registration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-compliance with para 3 rule 6 due to false certificate; ITO empowered under rule 6A to refuse if not satisfied application in order.

holdings.text: The conditions of registration prescribed by s. 26A and relevant rules apply equally to renewal of registration; if fulfilled, ITO bound to renew.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has ruled in Agarwal Co. v. Commissioner of .Income-tax, U.P.  1  that the companyditions of registration prescribed by s. 26-A and the relevant Rules are... The same rule will apply in the case of renewal of registration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in Agarwal Co.; renewal requires application in prescribed form including true certificate under para 3 rule 6.

holdings.text: The Supreme Court is bound by the findings of fact of the Tribunal regarding distribution of book and black profits.

anchor.surface_text: Now turning to the question referred to the High Court, that question is based on two findings of fact which are numbermore open to question. Those findings are  1  that the firm had distributed its book profits amongst the partners according to the Instrument of partnership,  2  but it had number distributed the profits earned by it in the black market amongst the six partners in accordance with the Instrument of partnership. ... We are bound by those findings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under s.66(1), referred question based on Tribunal facts not open to challenge in Supreme Court.

holdings.text: The question whether the application for renewal stood withdrawn is not before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Before examining the scope of the question submitted to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Act, we may mention that the question whether the application for renewal of registration stood withdrawn or number is number before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not part of referred question under s.66(1); Tribunal divided, President silent.

holdings.text: The certificate under paragraph 3 of rule 6 requires truthful statement that all profits of previous year (including unbooked) were divided or credited as shown, to prevent tax evasion.

anchor.surface_text: The reason behind rule 6 was that at the relevant time, the registered firm as such was number taxable. Only the partners of a firm companyld be taxed. That being so, if a portion of the profits earned by the firm was number divided amongst the partners or credited to their accounts, to that extent, the profits earned by the firm escaped assessment. Therefore the certificate companytemplated by rule 6 is number a mere formality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation: ensures partners taxed on shares; false certificate enables evasion by treating as registered firm.

precedents.citation: Agarwal Co. v. Commissioner of .Income-tax, U.P.  1

anchor.surface_text: Agarwal Co. v. Commissioner of .Income-tax, U.P.  1  that the conditions of registration prescribed by s. 26-A and the relevant Rules are On behalf of the firm, an application should be made to the Income-tax Officer by such person and at such times and containing such particulars, being in such form and verified in such manner as are prescribed by the rules The firm should be constituted under an instrument of partnership The instrument must specify the individual shares of the partners and The partnership must be valid and must actually exist in the terms specified in the instrument.

precedents.case_name: Agarwal Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Conditions of registration under s. 26A and relevant rules: proper application, constituted under instrument specifying shares, valid existing partnership; ITO bound to register if fulfilled; same for renewal
precedents.cited_holding: If those conditions are fulfilled, the Income-tax Officer is bound to register the firm

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-Tax, M. P. Nagpur and Bhandaru v. D Costa Brothers 1

Therein the Court held that the Income-tax Officer was number entitled to reject the application for registration of the deed of partnership of the assessee firm on the ground that the house-hold expenses of the partners were debited to the profit and loss account of the firm. Therein there was number 1  49, I.T.R. 181.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax, M. P. Nagpur and Bhandaru v. D Costa Brothers
precedents.cited_proposition: Income-tax Officer not entitled to reject registration on ground of household expenses debited to firm's profit and loss account

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Simla v. Sat Ram Gian Chand 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Simla v. Sat Ram Gian Chand 1 . Therein the partners first estimated the divisible profit and divided the same. The Court held that the division of profit was a matter relating to the internal affairs of the partnership and had numberbearing on the genuineness of the firm and that numberquestion of law arose from the order of the Appellate Tribunal.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Simla v. Sat Ram Gian Chand
precedents.cited_proposition: Division of profits is internal matter, no bearing on genuineness of firm for registration

precedents.citation: N. S. S. Chokkalingam Chettiar- and Co. C.I.T. Madras   2

anchor.surface_text: N. S. S. Chokkalingam Chettiar- and Co. C.I.T. Madras   2  . In that case though there was numberprovision in the deed of partnership for payment of salary to any of the partners, some of the partners were paid a salary in addition to the shares to which they were entitled under the terms of the partnership and the Income-tax Officer refused to register the firm on the ground that the profits were number divided in accordance with the partnership deed as some of the partners took an additional amount out of the profits in the shape of salary.

precedents.case_name: N. S. S. Chokkalingam Chettiar and Co. v. C.I.T. Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Payment of salary to partners despite no provision in deed not ground to refuse registration if genuine firm and proper application; salary deductible before divisible profits

precedents.citation: C.I.T., M.P. v. Mandanlal Chhagan Lal 3

anchor.surface_text: C.I.T., M.P. v. Mandanlal Chhagan Lal 3 . In that case the partnership deed provided that each partner will be entitled to interest at 6 per cent per annum on his capita investment and that the profit and loss will be divided equally among the partners after deducting the interest payable on the capital advances made by the partners.

precedents.case_name: C.I.T., M.P. v. Mandanlal Chhagan Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: Provision for interest on capital before dividing profits does not invalidate application for registration

precedents.citation: St. Josephs Provisions Store v. C.I.T., Kerala 1

anchor.surface_text: St. Josephs Provisions Store v. C.I.T., Kerala 1 . Therein the partners of the assessee firm resolved that the profits of the firm as disclosed in the profit and loss account need number be divided and credited in the profit and loss accounts of the partners, but should be credited to a reserve account but each of the partners to have an equal share in that amount.

precedents.case_name: St. Josephs Provisions Store v. C.I.T., Kerala
precedents.cited_proposition: Crediting undivided profits to reserve fund showing partners' shares satisfies rule 6 requirement for registration

anchor.surface_text: Whether the assessee firm which had distributed its book profits amongst the partners according to the Instrument of Partnership but which had number distributed the profits earned by it in the black market amongst the six partners in accordance with the Instrument of Partnership was entitled for renewal of registration for the assessment year 1948-49 ? The High Court answered that question in favour of the Department.

Hence we must hold that the application for renewal of registration made by the assessee did number companyply with companyditions prescribed in paragraph 3 of rule 6. Hence the Income-tax Officer was justified to refuse to renew the registration.

anchor.surface_text: As seen earlier, the finding of the Tribunal is that though the profits of the firm entered in its account books had been distributed, the profits earned but number entered into the account books have number been divided or credit in the account books. From that it follows that the certificate given in the application for renewal of registration is number a true certificate and further that a substantial portion of the profits earned had number been divided.

Hence we must hold that the application for renewal of registration made by the assessee did number companyply with companyditions prescribed in paragraph 3 of rule 6. Hence the Income-tax Officer was justified to refuse to renew the registration.

anchor.surface_text: The reason behind rule 6 was that at the relevant time, the registered firm as such was number taxable. Only the partners of a firm companyld be taxed. That being so, if a portion of the profits earned by the firm was number divided amongst the partners or credited to their accounts, to that extent, the profits earned by the firm escaped assessment. Therefore the certificate companytemplated by rule 6 is number a mere formality.

Hence we must hold that the application for renewal of registration made by the assessee did number companyply with companyditions prescribed in paragraph 3 of rule 6. Hence the Income-tax Officer was justified to refuse to renew the registration.
